aws::graph::propositions: # NTSB Administrative Information for Investigation 88191
Debra Eckrote is the Investigator In Charge (IIC) of investigation 88191.
The original publish date of the accident report is December 2, 2013.
The investigation is classified as a Class investigation.
The accident report documents the factual circumstances of the accident as described to the NTSB.
The investigation docket is available at https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=88191.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States.
The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) investigates significant events in other modes of transportation.
Other modes of transportation include railroad, transit, highway, marine, pipeline, and commercial space.
The NTSB determines the probable causes of the accidents and events it investigates.
The NTSB issues safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences.
The NTSB conducts transportation safety research studies.
The NTSB offers information and assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event it investigates.
The NTSB serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
The NTSB serves as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving mariner certificates issued by US Coast Guard.
The NTSB adjudicates appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the FAA.
The NTSB does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident.
NTSB accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties.
NTSB investigations are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person.
This policy is specified by Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4.
Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the NTSB's statutory mission.
The NTSB's statutory mission is to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations.
Title 49 United States Code section 1154(b) prohibits the admission into evidence or use of any part of an NTSB report in a civil action for damages.
A factual report that may be admissible under 49 United States Code section 1154(b) is available at the investigation docket.

text:
# Administrative Information

## Investigator In Charge (IIC):
Eckrote, Debra

## Additional Participating Persons:

## Original Publish Date:
December 2, 2013

## Last Revision Date:

## Investigation Class:
Class

## Note:
This accident report documents the factual circumstances of this accident as described to the NTSB.

## Investigation Docket:
[https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=88191](https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=88191)

The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) is an independent federal agency charged by Congress with investigating every civil aviation accident in the United States and significant events in other modes of transportationrailroad, transit, highway, marine, pipeline, and commercial space. We determine the probable causes of the accidents and events we investigate, and issue safety recommendations aimed at preventing future occurrences. In addition, we conduct transportation safety research studies and offer information and other assistance to family members and survivors for each accident or event we investigate. We also serve as the appellate authority for enforcement actions involving aviation and mariner certificates issued by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) and US Coast Guard, and we adjudicate appeals of civil penalty actions taken by the FAA.

The NTSB does not assign fault or blame for an accident or incident; rather, as specified by NTSB regulation, "accident/incident investigations are fact-finding proceedings with no formal issues and no adverse parties  and are not conducted for the purpose of determining the rights or liabilities of any person" (Title 49 Code of Federal Regulations section 831.4). Assignment of fault or legal liability is not relevant to the NTSB's statutory mission to improve transportation safety by investigating accidents and incidents and issuing safety recommendations. In addition, statutory language prohibits the admission into evidence or use of any part of an NTSB report related to an accident in a civil action for damages resulting from a matter mentioned in the report (Title 49 United States Code section 1154(b)). A factual report that may be admissible under 49 United States Code section 1154(b) is available [here](https://data.ntsb.gov/Docket?ProjectID=88191).
